summary: a total of 44 lessons learnt across the eight core capacities of IHR (2005). major themes included the need to mobilize and sustain political commitment. we did not find specific areas of weakness in monitoring IHR (2005). several outbreaks, epidemics and pandemics have been declared public health emergencies of international concern. IHR (2005) requires countries to develop, strengthen and maintain eight core public health capacities. by the end of 2015, 127 of the 192 countries had not met all core capacity requirements. we systematically evaluated published literature and reports for lessons learned from national experience in implementing IHR (2005). we systematically searched the PubMed®, Embase®, Global Health, We identified five global lessons learned from implementing multiple IHR (2005) core capacities. some major cross-cutting themes included the need for mobilizing and sustaining political commitment. defining fundamental data needs for new treatments and vaccines could help develop national research capacity. countries must consider how the IHR (2005) are to be implemented based on their national legal and governance context. to avoid having only vertical programmes, countries will have to decide how to integrate the IHR (2005) core capacity development into national legislation. health funding sources can be inflexible and unsustainable within national governance frameworks, but such funding could create momentum in generating domestic financing. identifying adequate funding is the first step to developing, strengthening and maintaining national IHR (2005) core capacities. if there remain persistent challenges in meeting the agreed IHR (2005) core capacity deadlines, trade tariffs, sanctions or embargoes might be needed to ensure countries collaborate fully in sustaining global health security. this could help accelerate the timeliness of providing essential surveillance data to the global health community. failure to implement IHR (2005) core capacities could adversely affect the international image of a country and increase its susceptibility to economic losses due to disease epidemics. countries that are yet to implement IHR (2005) core capacities may have insufficient human and financial resources to meet their obligations in near future. recent global epidemics have galvanized high-level political commitment towards ensuring global health security.
